Economic and infrastructural planning of an area should be done bearing in mind the environment conservation. To what extent do you agree with this statement? Provide reasons for your answer.

Country is said to be a well developed country when it has the capability to fulfil all the requirement of it`s people or it`s citizen. Economy and the infrastraucture that is available in any country determines the way it has been operating it`s work. With the changing environment and its degradation, it is of ought most important for any of the country to work for the upliftment the enviornment from its side as well. Environment is very important for any of the people as it is where a people live in. Being a part of it, every country should take it as the responsibility from its side to conserve the environment. 

 

Today, for any of the country to present itself to be well developed, it needs to make its economy strong enough, such that it is able to prove itself that it is doing well and it can do well in future as well. In this process of proving itself a better one they tend to neglect the environment and start doing the things that is not favourable for the enviornment. There has been so many things that is done by the country that completely destroys the environment. If one has to take any example then the easy one to consider is the destruction of forest with the aim to establish a better concrete houses, for industries and many more. With the aim to provide better faciltiy to the people and enhance the living standard of people, government introduces many facility, one of them is vehicle which produces a lot of smoke that is  not favourable for the environment.

 

Singapore, Honkong, United Kingdom, United states and many more developed countries are developed not because they considered environment but they considered developing economically by making the reforms that will generate the income for the country and raising the infrastructure facility to the people and to perform the work in a competitive mannner. Only with the rise in social medias, now it is starting to take interest on the environment

 

With the establishment of many organization who work for the conservation of the environment, it is brought into light that environment should also be focused along the economical development and infrastructural development. Environment is the place where any being can live, the degradation of it will directly be affecting the people and when the people are affected even the best of the best economy and infrastrusture cannot bring back what have already occured. So it is of utmost important for any of the country to take this in consideration and work on it. 

 

When any area is planned to be made with the economical and the infrastructural development, environment should also be considered. Environment is the birth place of every thing and the development ideas that is generated by the people, that people is a part of environment. So, when a plan is made to develop the country then it should never neglect the fact that protecting the environment is also equally important. The plans that are being made for economical and infrastructural development for any area should also include the plan to conserve and protect the environment. Being a part of environment, it is a huge responsibiltiy to protect the environment. The initiative is taken by the philosophy of corporate social responsibility by the big corporates and it should be considered by other`s as well. Many reforms should also be made for the conservation of the environment.

India Economic Outlook

India remained remarkably resilient from the global economic turmoil in 2008 owing to its strong domestic fundamentals and had been one of the fastest economies to recover from the crisis. Currently, the growth momentum of the Indian economy has again been impacted. This time around besides the prevailing crisis in some of the developed economies, emergence of certain domestic issues had played a major role in restraining India’s growth momentum. However, we believe that India’s long term growth prospects will remain buoyant driven by its underlying strong macroeconomic fundamentals. We believe that emphasis on boosting investment activity and setting up of a favorable policy environment will act as a catalyst to unravel the growth potential of the Indian economy during the current decade.

The highlights of the analysis have been provided below –

 

India’s macro-economic outlook 2020:

 

India is expected to be more than US$ 5 trillion (current market price) economy by FY20.

The size of the Indian economy will be comparable to the Japanese economy (in terms of GDP in US$) as of 2010

We expect the current phase of subdued growth to continue till FY15 before the economy moves into a high growth phase

India’s economic growth during the current decade is expected to be driven by the buoyancy in the services sector

Investment activity is expected to accelerate going ahead, which will help the Indian economy achieve a higher growth rate. Share of investment to GDP will increase to stand at 40.7% of GDP during FY20 from 36.6% during FY10

Infrastructure will be both a cause and a consequence of economic growth during the current decade

 

Strong growth in domestic savings will support domestic investment. The savings rate is expected to surge to 39.5% during FY20 from 33.8% during FY10

 

Under consumption, share of discretionary spending is expected to rise significantly to 70% of private final consumption expenditure (PFCE) as compared to 60.0% (P) in FY11

 

Economic growth drivers:

 

Substantial investments in social and physical infrastructure will be the key growth drivers that will enable the economy to achieve ‘inclusive growth’ over the current decade

Infrastructure investment in the electricity sector is expected to account for 3.8% of GDP by FY20

Investment in physical infrastructure is expected to lead to employment generation, increased production efficiency, reduction in cost of doing business and improved standard of living which is expected to drive infrastructure investment (as measured by Gross Fixed Capital Formation) to 11.5% of GDP by FY20 from around 6.0% (BE) of GDP in FY12

Increased government focus towards improving overall healthcare facilities is expected to enhance total government expenditure on healthcare to 2.2% of GDP in FY20, as against 1.3% (BE) of GDP in FY12

The share of the private sector in infrastructure financing is expected to increase from 39.4% in FY12 (P) to 48.0% in FY20

Investment in the agriculture sector is expected to grow to around 3.2% of GDP by FY20 as against 2.6% (BE) of GDP in FY12
